Reviewer_1.Reviewer_1.1.1: The third sector, its definition and description is missing.  The third sector in Europe, Edward Elgar, spesifically discuss whether cooperations are defined within or outside the third sector.
Reviewer_1.Reviewer_1.1.2: The case description and analysis is based only on media accounts - no actual first hand information to inform the analysis.
Reviewer_1.Reviewer_1.1.3: I also have problems with the depth of the discussion, and I feel the conclusion does not match the promises of the abstract.
Reviewer_1.Reviewer_1.1.4: Wrong reference number on page 4, line 14: should be 15
Reviewer_1.Reviewer_1.1.5: Figure 1 text overwrite part of the figure, and there should be comments on how this is different from a general structure for a private sector company (if you look at stakeholders as shareholders)
Reviewer_1.Reviewer_1.1.6: Bottom of page 9: Missing reference to Co-operative principles by Rochdale Society.
Reviewer_1.Reviewer_1.1.7: USA context concerning cooperatives (upper half page 10) should be highlighted even more for readers to be able to compare to their own context (for instance in Europe)
Reviewer_1.Reviewer_1.1.8: The cooperative firm removes adversarial aspects of market contracting (page 11) - what adversarial aspects?
Reviewer_1.Reviewer_1.1.9: are references 27 and 33 used in the text? (could not find them)
Reviewer_1.Reviewer_1.3.1: However, I cannot see how chapter 2.2. is a sub-theme under the Ostrom Principles? If they are - the connection need explainnig. If they are not, the main headling Chapter 2 should be reformulated again.
Reviewer_1.Reviewer_1.3.2: I still miss a source reference at the bottom of page 9 (Rochdale Society)
Reviewer_1.Reviewer_1.3.3: On top of page 11 there is still no examples of adversarial effects removed by co-operative.
Reviewer_1.Reviewer_1.3.4: The author openly acknowledges that the basis for a complete picture is lacking. I do not expect the complete picture, but should have comments on limitations and to what degree the conclusions and learnings are possible to generalize.
Reviewer_1.Reviewer_1.3.5: Conclusion: middle of page 16: "we cannot know the motivations behind.." Have you tried to talk to them? I believe it is possible to get to know.
Reviewer_1.Reviewer_1.3.6: Low on page 16: "The ownership becomes absentee, ..." This is in the case of co-operative?

Author.Author.2.1: I hope that the revisions in the abstract an introduction better clarify the purpose.
Author.Author.2.2: Agreed. I accounted for this throughout the document. Terminology is used in a definitionally consistent manner.
Author.Author.2.3: Note that I adjusted the paper, and recalibrated it from a case study, to a discussion paper that utilizes an archival analysis of secondary sources.
Author.Author.2.4: Noted and accounted for throughout the document.
Author.Author.2.5: Acknowledged. I cleaned and honed the Introduction, and added a more robust Conclusion.
Author.Author.2.6: Agreed. The Analysis, Discussiom, and Conclusion sections are more fleshed out.
Author.Author.2.8: As per your suggestions, I did focus on the co-operative model
Author.Author.4.1: I have changed the headings for these sections to better reflect the content.
Author.Author.4.2: This is general knowledge, thereby not necessitating a reference. If the reviewers disagree, I would add a reference.
Author.Author.4.3: I have added commentary about moral hazard and information asymetries.
Author.Author.4.4: Agreed. I have added additional elaboration.
Author.Author.4.5: Commentary added, nothing the need for additiona interogation.

Reviewer_2.Reviewer_2.1.1: The abstract of the manuscript mentions that dominant modes of third sector organizational governance adhere to a narrow principal-agent orientation. Similarly, in the introduction, it is stated that governance research on third sector organizations predominantly fixates analysts on the board-management dynamic
Reviewer_2.Reviewer_2.1.2: In the abstract, the author also states that the over-reliance on the principal-agent model introduces two challenges. However, a solid foundation for this argument is missing
Reviewer_2.Reviewer_2.1.3: In the introduction, the author also mentions underdeveloped modes of stakeholder governance in the third sector. I do not agree with this view. Several stakeholder governance frameworks for third sector organizations have already been developed in the literature
Reviewer_2.Reviewer_2.1.4: The author uses “stakeholder-controlled firm”, “third sector organizations”, “nonprofit organizations”, “social enterprise”, and “co-operative” without clearly defining these types and mentioning which nonprofit type is actually the focus of the study.
Reviewer_2.Reviewer_2.1.5: I am also not convinced by the definition of co-operatives mentioned in the paper.
Reviewer_2.Reviewer_2.1.6: Furthermore, given that the world of third sector organizations is very rich and heterogeneous, one should be careful by discussing third sector organizations in general, especially since the case study seems to focus on co-operative enterprises.
Reviewer_2.Reviewer_2.1.7: The literature review is completely missing.
Reviewer_2.Reviewer_2.1.8: Given the aforementioned comments, I would advise the author to revise the paper by focusing on the governance of nonprofit associations / co-operatives.

Reviewer_3.Reviewer_3.1.1: However, there are subtleties in the literature that need considering, and also the methodology (which is extremely weak).
Reviewer_3.Reviewer_3.1.2: The characterisation of third sector governance is too crude.
Reviewer_3.Reviewer_3.1.3: Given the inclusion of Coule's paper, I would have already expected more sensitivity to divisions unitary and pluralist theories of governance but by reviting this (and reading Turnbull's Cornforth's and Ridley-Duff's precursor to Coule's work), this should be adequately addressed.
Reviewer_3.Reviewer_3.1.4: I just can't agree that third sector governance is derived from for-profit principles.
Reviewer_3.Reviewer_3.1.5: Certainly, some description of the process by which the case study was developed (sources used, data collection techniquies, analysis techniques) are needed to be publishable.
Reviewer_3.Reviewer_3.1.6: The framework for this section exists but feels a bit superficial and under-developed. I think it needs linking back to the findings more clearly and to be elaborated and slightly more length (cut some literature if needed to stay within the word length limits).
Reviewer_3.Reviewer_3.1.7: Lastly, the discussion and conclusions need to stick to contributions to theory / research practice and refrain from commenting on wider issues without adequate justification.

Reviewer_4.Reviewer_4.1.1: I do not understand the purpose of the paper.
Reviewer_4.Reviewer_4.1.2: The author is mixing up several concepts and ignore the abundant literature on governance in nonprofits not dealing with the agency theory.
Reviewer_4.Reviewer_4.1.3: The style is more journalistic and free opinion than rigourous research.
Reviewer_4.Reviewer_4.1.4: Public enterprises, third sector cooperatives are all mixedup.
Reviewer_4.Reviewer_4.1.5: The conceptual framework is not clearly presented and I do not see what are the contributions except some free statements at the end not really related to the analysis.
